title: 110_s599
content: The "Private Disaster Loans Act of 2007" may be cited as the Short Title. It pertains to private disaster loans. The Small Business Act is amended to include a new subsection (c) regarding Private Disaster Loans. Definitions for "disaster area" and "eligible small business concern" are provided in this subsection. The Small Business Act of 1958 is amended to include a new subsection (c) for Private Disaster Loans. A qualified private lender can issue loans to eligible small businesses in disaster areas, guaranteed by the Administrator. The loans can be used for any purpose authorized under subsection (b), and an online application process may be established for convenience. The Administrator may coordinate with other federal agencies for additional disaster relief assistance programs through an online application process. Consultation with public and private sectors, including private lenders, is required. Maximum amounts for loan guarantees are determined by the Administrator. The Administrator may guarantee up to 85% of a loan, with a maximum amount of $2,000,000. The loan term can be up to 15 years without collateral and 25 years with collateral. No guarantee fee is collected, but an origination fee may be paid to a qualified private lender. The Administrator may guarantee up to 85% of a loan, with a maximum amount of $2,000,000, for a term of up to 15 years without collateral and 25 years with collateral. A qualified private lender can charge an origination fee for a guaranteed loan, with the amount agreed upon in advance. The lender may use its own loan documentation, as authorized by the Administrator, without it being a criteria for qualification. The Administrator is required to issue final regulations within one year of the enactment of the Private Disaster Loans Act of 2007. The Administrator will issue final regulations for qualified private lenders under the Private Disaster Loans Act of 2007. A report on the progress of these regulations must be submitted to Congress within 6 months. Appropriations for this subsection will be made available from funds appropriated to the Administration. The amendments allow the Administrator to reduce interest rates by up to 3 percentage points for disaster loans. The effective date applies to disasters declared before, on, or after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. TECHNICAL AND CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. The Small Business Act is amended in sections 4(c) and 7(b) to update references and provisions related to loan interest rates. The Small Business Act is amended to update loan interest rate provisions.
